newsitem.title: USA: Computer Assoc merger deal puzzles analysts.
newsitem.headline: Computer Assoc merger deal puzzles analysts.

text.p: Computer Associates International Inc's plan to acquire Cheyenne Software Inc in a deal worth about $1.2 billion met with initial puzzlement from Wall Street and industry analysts Monday.
Analysts said that with only sketchy terms available, it was not evident how Computer Associates could justify paying the rich price of seven times Cheyenne's trailing revenues.
In addition, they said, the terms of the merger represent a sharp departure by Computer Associates from its traditional bargain-hunting, patchwork acquisition model.
"This is a departure from their standard practice," UBS Securities analyst Joseph Farley said.
"They are paying more than they ever have" in relation to the target company's revenues, he said.
Cheyenne reported revenues of $174.1 million in its fiscal year ended June 1996.
"There's clearly some synergies," Farley said. "The question is whether those synergies are worth seven times sales."
He added, "They have never paid more than three or three-and-a-half times sales, So you have to seriously evaluate this transaction."
In the absence of further details, the analyst said he was withholding further judgment on the terms of the merger.
The initial reaction by Computer Associates investors was muted. The shares gained slightly to 63, up 5/8 on the day, on moderate volume of just over 700,000 shares.
Cheyenne's stock rocketed to 30, up 7-5/8 and just a half-point under the $30.50 cash per share that Computer Associates plans to offer Cheyenne holders.
Volume approached 9.3 million Cheyenne shares by early afternoon.

The merger would bring together Cheyenne, a supplier of storage management software, with Computer Associates, which makes systems management software designed to manage the operations of entire computer networks.
Computer Associates has acquired roughly 60 companies over the past two decades, mainly as a way of filling in missing pieces in its core systems management product line.

Paul Mason, an enterprise software analyst with technology research firm International Data Corp in Framingham, Mass., said the acquisition does not fit what he called "the CA model, both in terms of acquisitions and product strategy."

"It's hard to see where this fits in. If they were getting this at a great price, I could understand the deal," he said. Like Farley, Mason said he was adopting a wait-and-see attitude until the companies provide more details on the deal.
The companies were to hold a press conference in New York at 1300 EDT/1700 GMT on Monday. They were expected to provide further details of the motivations behind the merger.

"The CA acquisiton model has been one of bottom-fishing," Mason said, mainly as a means of filling out its core systems management business. However, he said that lately CA has been willing to pay more for new technology.

Mason said Cheyenne's storage management software fails to provide Computer Associates with a unified, "open systems" platform that CA could plug into its own existing CA/Unicenter systems management platform.
By contrast, Legato Systems Inc storage management products could provide Computer Associates with a ready-built system to work with CA/Unicenter, he said. "Why didn't they buy Legato?" Mason asked.

Cheyenne faces increasing competition from rivals such as Seagate Technology Inc's Seagate Software unit in Cheyenne's core business of providing storage management software used with Novell Inc NetWare.
Cheyenne says it derived about 75 percent of its revenues from its NetWare-related business in fiscal 1996.

Mason said Seagate is better positioned to compete with Cheyenne in this area since it has no existing NetWare business to defend. "A price war in NetWare backup would hurt Cheyenne a lot more than Seagate," he said.
-- New York Newsdesk 212-859-1736
